captions.text: The messages this season complete the previous seasons, they do not contradict them
Guide us to the Straight Path
Housing Solutions
One of the greatest challenges of our time is the ability to provide decent housing solutions for our populations
Let's take a look at some modern housing solutions around the world
What's this?
It's one type of housing solution... and as you can guess, we're in Japan
Tokyo is a very congested city and land is really expensive so they've come up with creative ways to maximize space
This house is one example. It's owned by one person who lives alone. The land itself is around 16 square meters
Its about 4 meters by 4 meters..... actually less than 4 meters [in width]
The house itself is built on 11.5 squared meters
There's a basement (bedroom), a ground floor, two other floors and there's even a roof
So this is the entrance. You'll notice that every millimeter of the space is utilized to the max
This is the kitchen... there's an electric stove-top; underneath is a dishwasher
Just because it's a small space, it doesn't mean that you have to give up on the necessities... they're all here and more
Even things that are considered luxuries, like this dishwasher, are here

There's a TV, toaster, etc..
So that was the ground floor
Let's look at how the size of homes in the USA has changed over time
In 1950 the average size of a home for an average family (four members) was 100 square meters
In 2013, the average family size shrunk to 3 members... while the size of homes doubled to 200 square meters
This suggests that in the 1950s American families lived in houses with just enough space to fulfill their needs
But with the boom [in housing/spending], Americans started living in houses that are bigger than what they require
And began to buy houses [of sizes] based on their wants rather than needs
Even in the West, there are still places where house size is based on need rather than desires

In the USA, average house size is 200 square meters
While in Germany, it's half of that, 100 square meters

95 square meters in Japan
83 square meters in Sweden, which is another rich country
In the United Kingdom, the average home size is only 76 square meters!
So obviously having bigger living space and homes is not the only housing solution
The important thing is to own your living space
Each nation has its own culture with regards to living space, size of homes, land, and access to land for ownership, etc
The great thing about Japanese homes is that they comply with the principle that small houses can fulfill one's needs
Having a small house doesn't mean that you're poor or that it is sparingly furnished and doesn't meet your needs
You can have a small house and limited space with all the necessities and furnishings for your enjoyment
The office is on the first floor, I think the owner is a graphic designer
Look at that view - you can make a small space look bigger just by having a window
See, that's the third TV in the house
The second floor houses the bathroom, including the washing machine. That's the fourth TV
There's a bathtub and a roof where the owner occasionally sits
This is Ihsan [excellence] in maximizing space
That's the fourth TV... take a picture of me and the plasma screen
The monthly costs [utilities] are less burdensome because there's less space and requires less electricity like air conditioning and lights
This is a solution from Tokyo that embodies ihsan [excellence]
In the Arab world there isn't a problem with a lack of space, but we'll get back to that
The problem with spaces, even in the Arab world, is how expensive they are and people can't afford to buy land
One solution, which also applies to the Arab world where space is plentiful but land is expensive,
is to allow people to buy small parcels of land that meet their needs and is within their budget
In some Arab countries, for example, the smallest size land you can buy for a small flat or villa is 250 square meters
What if someone buys 50 square meters? The house we saw in Japan was built on 16 square meters of land
What if one was content with that size of land and I wanted to build a house on 50 square meters of land - not even 16?
They wouldn't be able to because the land registry plans are developed such that 250 square meters is the minimum size
Even in the USA, where space isn't an issue but land prices are rising, they've started building smaller houses
Americans have begun to live in smaller houses that just fulfill their needs and are foregoing larger spaces
This house is 46 square meters - so it's a small space but it's in fact a house not a flat
Just to clarify, we're not suggesting that people who can afford a larger house should live in small spaces
Those that Allah has bestowed upon the means to afford it, go ahead while relying on Allah
[Quranic verse] "But as for the favor of your Lord, report [it]." [93:11]
In an economic crisis though, one solution is to live in smaller houses- like Jay
As space is becoming increasingly limited, companies have started producing clever, space-maximizing furniture

So did you see that? I think the idea's pretty clear
From an end table to a dining table that seats 10
When you're done, [collapses it back into an end table]
That's all there is to it
These are clever ways to maximize space. The idea is that when you're not using the bed, the area is dead space
It's taking up space from the house and has no purpose the whole day
So by using the space the bed would occupy for other purposes, we're maximizing it without constraining movement
Slums are another grave problem, both in the Arab world and elsewhere.
What are 'slums'? They are informal settlements that people have populated without proper planning
Consequently, slums cannot offer decent living conditions because of their informal nature and the lack of planning
The living conditions here do not embody ihsan [excellence]
Millions of human beings live in these slums across the Arab world
It's not just a problem in the Arab world; many other countries have faced these challenges and many have solved them
We should always look for solutions in the East and West,
In Mexico, for example, they have slums but they've found some solutions

Look at some of the houses they've built in these areas
They build 600,000 housing units each year
This is one type of solution from the West
Let's go to the far East- in this case South Korea
They had a major problem related to slums in the 1950s and 60s, and it was a poor country at the time
One of the solutions they came up with was to build large apartment buildings (24 floors) that maximize space
The buildings were outside the city center to minimize prices and people from the slums in the city center were moved there
The slums became unpopulated and were then removed to build more housing.
This picture shows one such project. One part is slums not yet demolished while big buildings are built to replace them
We should remember that neither the government nor the private sector on their own can solve the problem
The government needs to encourage this with investments from the private sector
In this way, housing problems can be solved
We found another solution for slums in the United Kingdom...
There are thousands of abandoned shipping containers just lying around
They can be re-purposed and transformed for housing purposes
There are many solutions for people with low incomes in the UK, this is one of them:
Wow, that's impressive. This flat costs $25,000 (about $100,000 riyals) and is fully furnished
This is another type of solution that officials and businessmen in the Arab world should look into and contact us for more info
If space is not an issue in the Arab world, as it is plentiful - what is the problem?
One of the biggest obstacles is rising prices. A major factor behind this is the growing phenomenon of 'white land'

What's this? 
This is what is known as 'white land'
They are huge spaces in the middle of cities which people own and haven't been altered or used for tens of years
This has led to housing crises because it reduces the supply of land available and consequently increases prices
In some Arab cities, 45%, imagine, of the land is white land - huge tracts of unused land in the middle of cities
This is not an exception; there are millions of parcels of white land in the Arab world
This problem even existed in the time of the companions in Madina
The Prophet (PBUH) had given land to one of the companions but it remained unused until Omar became Caliph
Omar told the man "The Prophet (PBUH) did not give you land rights to withhold it from the people,but rather for you to use
Take some of it which you can build on and return the rest"
Omar's rationale was that these land rights were bestowed upon him but he didn't make use of it
The Prophet (PBUH), the leader of Madina, didn't give those rights to be withheld from people and create a shortage
The land I'm standing on right now has an area of one million square meters - 1000 meters X 1000 meters
If this land was developed - including using 40% for public parks and amenities - and only building on 60% of the land
700 buildings could be developed, each 8 stories tall - for a total of 20,000 apartments
The apartments would be spacious - 200 square meters, adequate for 5 people
In total, this one piece of land, owned by one person, can support 100,000 people
Hence, one of the modern solutions promoted by scholars and economists is to impose zakat or taxes on these lands
Why? Landowners won't be able to afford to keep land unaltered if they were to pay yearly zakat or taxes
They would then have two options: either to develop the land, which would have public benefit, or sell it to someone who will
This has worked in some Arab countries where this principle has been applied
There are still some Arab countries where this hasn't been introduced and land has remained unaltered for decades
Hence it's said that ownership is not in possessing land but by developing it
It's not enough to have a deed for a land and 'sit on it' to really 'own' it
To prove ownership you have to actually use the ownership rights
We found a solution to the problem of 'white land' in the UK that can be applied in the Arab world
This spacious piece of land was converted and divided into smaller pieces and mobile housing units were installed
We came across this area by accident and were told that these were mobile home solutions
This is one such installation, and we're going to learn more from Mr. Terry
He's paying around 40 pounds a month to rent the area. He owns his house, which is built in a factory and installed here
One of the advantages of this solution is that the spacious land is developed with a plan in mind - like this parking lot
The lots are divided among residents and different sizes can be rented out
Terry's house is on 50 square meters of land while the next house utilizes two lots

It's very comfortable and affordable:
Rent is less than $100 USD a month
Plus, the house, which you own, only costs 400 thousand riyals or about $100 thousand dollars
Another advantage is that these houses are mobile and can be moved to new locations
After the houses are installed, you can connect it to plumbing, electricity, etc.
This solution can solve housing shortages
I hope that there is more movement, and no obstructions, to implement housing solutions in the Arab world
[Good] housing is the foundation that can invigorate a renaissance in our part of the world
All developing nations that converged to become rich countries needed to solve two huge and important problems:
Corruption (which we've spoken about on other occasions) and housing
